item.title: Group 1 [Spatial Resolution]
item.description: In a web browser, search for “bike path Cambridge gis data download”. Visit any relevant results. Make observations. Which file types are available for access? How would you get this into a GIS? What are the categories or attribute information? Is this data available in a GIS format, or is it a table with geographic information? If it is GIS data, which kind of layer is it? Point, line, or polygon?

item.title: Group 2 [Portals]
Group 3 [Turning Spreadsheets into Spatial Data]
item.description: Visit the documentation page for data about Boston 311 service requests , to get a sense of what this dataset shows. Observe the data categories in the PDF codebook. Now glance at the actual 311 requests dataset for 2024 from Analyze Boston. Observe a few records to get a sense of how this table is filled out. There are two different ways to turn this dataset into spatial data. If you want the data to show up as individual occurrences (each 311 request is one dot on the map), you can use the latitude and longitude coordinate fields to import the data table to a GIS software, effectively turning it into a shapefile, geojson or geopackage.
